title: Open Data Maturity Model (2024)
description:
The open data maturity model is a way to assess how well an organisation publishes and consumes open data, and identifies actions for improvement.

The model is based around five themes and five progress levels. Each theme represents a broad area of operations within an organisation. Each theme is then broken into areas of activity, which can then be used to assess progress.

statements.text: There is little or no published open data.
statements.context: Some notes to go with this statement

statements.text: Datasets that are published are done so using ad hoc and possibly manual processes, and are only available on the organisationâ€™s own regular website.
Released datasets are rarely, if ever, updated.
Licensing may not be explicitly addressed, meaning that published data is open to view but not open to use.
Specific teams or projects may have defined a repeatable data publishing process, but this is inconsistent across the organisation.
URLs are becoming standardised and persistent and directly link to data.
Some datasets are released and updated according to a regular schedule.
Datasets are published under an open data licence, making them not just open to view but also open to use.
There is a repeatable organisation-wide release process for publishing datasets, with a defined cadence of data release.
The release process has been adopted for some published datasets, but not all.
Datasets are usually published on a dedicated open data portal under a conformant open data licence.
There is a central catalogue of published datasets, which is at least moderately complete.
All published datasets are released according to the standard organisational process.
Datasets are published using an open source data portal, which has robust data management features.
All datasets have unique and persistent identifiers and direct URLs.
Archived versions of key datasets are provided to support historical analysis.
Updates to datasets are released to a scheduled, published timetable.

The dataset catalogue is mostly complete regarding old datasets, and is always written to in full for new datasets as part of the release and update process, which is likely to be automatic. This is externally available.
Internal reports are available to highlight stale datasets.
The organisation collects and monitors metrics on its release process, e.g. time taken to release and refresh datasets.
The organisation acts to optimise the release process to reduce time between changes and releases.
Datasets are also made available through open data aggregation and indexing platforms.
The release process includes steps to consider how open data may be used to support Artificial Intelligence / Machine Learning (AI/ML) use cases
Datasets are not released using common standards.
Data is in a variety of formats, with no official quality control.
Some teams or projects may have agreed on specific technical standards for formatting certain types of data, but these are inconsistent across projects and not always applied.
Standards are driven by internal priorities and needs, with no consideration for data re-users.

Data is typically in structured formats (e.g. tabular form), which are human readable but often not machine-readable (e.g. decorative formatting), and which may also be proprietary (e.g. XLS rather than XLSX). Primary data sets are free of major errors, but formatting issues may remain.
Some metadata is gathered and published alongside the data, but with no standard content or format.

The organisation has defined a set of key technical data publishing standards which is internally available and frequently used. These standards address data formats (e.g. they demand non-proprietary structured formats such as XLSX or CSV) and metadata needs, including the use of schemas.
Metadata is fairly complete and well structured, adhering to the same quality standards applied to the data itself.
Most data sets are machine readable. Column headings and data are all standardised and clear for primary datasets, with separate lookup tables often used to explain codes and terms.
All datasets are released in conformance with the organisation's technical standards.
Datasets across the organisation are using standard code lists and identifiers. Relevant datasets are using open options.
Metadata is always considered alongside the primary data, with distinct descriptive and structural aspects. Standard open formats such as DCAT are beginning to be adopted.
The organisation has defined a strategic approach for managing its data standards going forwards.
The organisation monitors technology trends to ensure that its datasets are released according to evolving standards and best practices.
The organisation is routinely using open standards, including code lists and identifiers, to help align its datasets with other sources. The same can be said of metadata too.
The organisation is using specific standards with the explicit intention of making data AI/ML-ready.
Datasets are not managed in any consistent way.
There is no clear ownership around internal datasets.
Data ethics is not actively considered.
Specific teams or products have begun defining their own lightweight data governance processes, which are used ad hoc.
Specific individuals are aware of data ethics, but there is no standard way to consider it across projects.
The organisation has defined a standard data governance process that has been applied to high value datasets.
The process addresses key organisational issues and considers the complete dataset lifecycle.
Datasets have a well-defined owner through their lifecycle.
The standard data governance process is applied to all datasets. The process may be tailored to the needs of specific projects.
The organisation routinely monitors data quality for its high-value datasets.
Feedback from re-users is used to help drive improvements in data quality where appropriate.
The organisation is working to improve its data governance processes, e.g. by monitoring the process to address circumstances where data governance may lapse.
The organisation is working in partnership with re-users to help improve & maintain data quality. This may include accepting external contributions.
The organisation recognises that there may be risks associated with data, but has not yet defined any processes for assessing and mitigating them.
Datasets that contain sensitive information are simply avoided, and are not considered for release at all.
Processes for assessing and mitigating risks are defined, but they are applied ad hoc.

Some datasets based on sensitive information are released, following efforts made to remove or aggregate data. Where personal information is released, appropriate consent or other legal basis is obtained.
Standard processes for assessing and mitigating risks are defined, such as anonymisation and aggregation, and they are routinely applied to new datasets as deemed necessary.
Risk management is an explicit component of the data governance process.
Standard risk assessments and mitigations are applied to all datasets prior to publication. The organisation may also apply a standardised open data triage process.
Advanced Privacy Enhancing Technologies (PETs) may be employed to open data.
The organisation seeks independent validation prior to release of high risk datasets.
The organisation routinely assesses all datasets during their life-cycle in order to highlight sensitive information. An open data triage process is in place that is also published or linked to.

The organisation monitors the changing data landscape to address emerging issues, including those poised by AI. This may involve changing the approach to risk assessment and mitigation, or even stopping a data release.
Current open data activities rely on existing knowledge and skills of a small number of stakeholders and/or self-taught evangelists.
Expertise across the roles is undefined. Utilisation and resourcing is managed on an ad-hoc basis, with no/limited documented evidence of existing knowledge and skills in relation to open data.
There is limited understanding of which roles are directly linked to open data practices, and there is no/limited detail of open data activities in job descriptions of key roles.
The organisation has data professionals embedded. These may be organised as a single team, or dispersed across teams.
Training and support around open data is driven by the needs of specific projects as they arise.
Where there is a need for expertise that is not readily available, the organisation relies on external expertise for key open data skills.
The organisation has identified internal open data experts that may help support and mentor others.
There may be a data focused working group of interested parties working on data related projects.
The organisation has several staff members with the necessary skills to implement data initiatives. These roles are typically centrally organised and focus on organisational projects.
The organisation is actively building a shared understanding of open data practices. This covers common knowledge, operational requirements and strategic insight.
Open data awareness and training becomes a standard part of staff induction and/or development.
Staff are clear on how open data guides and informs organisational strategy.

There are individuals responsible for managing open data. This includes reviewing processes and/or maintaining data sets. These individuals are champions for open data and build connections between open data and other data domains.
Teams across the organisation have a data champion who advocates on behalf of the team regarding strategic goals managed locally.
Knowledge and understanding of open data exists at all levels in the organisation.
Staff understand the impact of their own roles and responsibilities regarding open data.
The organisation acts to build and foster networks of open data expertise both within the organisation and the wider community.
The organisation is formally exploring the ethical impacts of open data and examining how ethical data practices can support open data.
The organisation is looking to advance its open data practices by examining its maturity in other areas of data.
Non-data professionals are included in key committees and stakeholder groups to discuss impact of projects and outcomes across the organisation.
When reviewing individuals' learning and development, competencies or performance, the process does not include any focus on data literacy and skills.
There is no standard learning needs analysis for data literacy and skills.
There are limited opportunities/resources for individuals to learn more about data.
There is no shared understanding of data in the organisation, although some areas of expertise are developing.
Recognition of data expertise is typically focused on direct data roles. The organisation has limited awareness of data skills within operational and strategic roles.
There are existing processes for individuals to undertake learning, but they rely on individuals identifying their own learning needs and identifying appropriate resources.
Professionals are encouraged to identify learning needs in relation to data during their competency/performance review processes.
The organisation has undertaken a learning needs analysis, and has identified key data skills for development.

Awareness of data learning needs may be high-level and lack specificity across the domains (open, ethics, strategy). Identified provision may be focused on baselining skills, rather than advancing expertise.
There is recognition of which teams or individuals require data upskilling. There may also be an increasing awareness of the ethical impacts of open data.
The organisation has a repeatable process for conducting learning needs analysis that includes data as a theme, and manages this on an annual/bi-annual basis.

The organisation has KPIs for data upskilling, and measures engagement with learning opportunities across the workforce. This may still focus on baseline skills rather than advancing expertise. However, there is likely some provision for advancing key skills aligned to business needs and strategy.
Data skills development is an area of development for all colleagues, identified as part of their performance or competency review.
Training provision is adapted based on outcomes of the regular learning needs analysis.
KPIs are defined and understood. They measure learning beyond engagement, and emphasise the application of skills within work.
Learning strategy is closely aligned to organisational strategy, and the organisation is able to identify capability risks, and sustainably manage adaptability across the workforce.
There are KPIs that align learning impact to business impact, such as growth, transformation, productivity and profitability.
There is no strategic ownership of data within the organisation.
The organisation may provide tool specific training (e.g. Excel), but does not provide any direct training for open data.
Provision is typically focused on access to knowledge rather than learning (i.e. how-to content repositories, rather than application of skills).
The organisation has appointed a strategic owner for data, but there is limited focus on skills development.

Data literacy and skills courses may be internally available. These are typically generic and non-specific to job role or purpose. Learning may include data analysis, data organising and structuring, or high level concepts such as data ethics.
Strategic ownership includes learning as a key focus area.
Training and support around open data is offered to some teams as standard. This is largely focused on building operational skills (e.g. licensing, technology).
Learning resources are appropriately categorised to support individuals in identifying the most appropriate learning for their need.
There may be some learning identified and actively suggested to individuals across the organisation.
Staff across the organisation are clear on the need for developing data skills, and the impact this has on their role and responsibilities, as well as the broader organisational goals.

The organisation has implemented programmes of learning in relation to data. Teams and departments have loosely documented responsibilities for individuals in their areas and advise/feedback on the availability and suitability of learning provision.
Where there is limited data expertise in a team, the organisation manages support through dedicated resources in centrally managed teams.

Staff across the organisation are aware of the training provision available, and have identified their specific needs for development, and understand where to receive additional guidance on developing in additional areas.
There are individuals who actively engage in piloting new learning opportunities to meet future business needs and anticipated changes in strategic direction.

Learning provision is nuanced, and provides introductory, intermediate and advanced literacy and skills. This goes beyond generic offerings and focuses directly on specific areas of expertise. It includes learning related to data governance, infrastructure and operations, as well as data ethics and its application to open data.
Little or no attempt is made to identify potential re-users for released open data.
Information about stakeholders is held by individuals, siloed within the organisation.
Data releases are  reactively driven by short-term internal priorities, or based on ad hoc demands from re-users.
The organisation's motivations for data releases are not communicated clearly to stakeholders.
The organisation has little or no engagement with other organisations in its sector.
No attempt is made to measure levels of engagement.
Some teams attempt to identify and engage with potential re-users of the datasets they are publishing.
Some information about stakeholders is shared and co-ordinated between teams or departments.
The organisation has established a means by which potential re-users can request data.
Some ad hoc attempts are made to assess the impact of data publishing efforts.
There is some ad hoc engagement with individual organisations in the same sector to share knowledge
Key stakeholders are identified and mapped, with a system in place for storing and co-ordinating information centrally.
The organisation has established a repeatable approach for engaging with external users which is tailored, as appropriate, to support individual data releases.
The engagement process includes outreach to the community both before and after the release of data.
The organisation begins to actively seek user demand for data, in order to guide its engagement strategy and inform data releases.
The organisation engages with groups or organisations in its sector and plays a reactive role in supporting the improvement of open data practices.

Stakeholder analysis is regularly conducted to inform strategic thinking about the management of stakeholder engagement, with clear links between engagement strategies and the overarching aims and objectives of the organisation and its stakeholders.
The organisation begins tracking the effectiveness of its interventions as an open data publisher, identifying standard ways to measure and monitor the impact of key data releases.
The organisation plays an active role in supporting open data initiatives in its sector.
The organisation is working to increase engagement within identified, high-value stakeholder communities and for high-value datasets.
The organisation is routinely tracking metrics relating to all its open data publishing efforts.

The organisation proactively engages with its sector and takes a leading role in the improvement of open data practices and the promotion of further open data activities. This may include innovation challenges and dedicated community engagement groups.
The organisation has clear processes for collaborating with peers on establishing best practice.
Datasets are released with little or no documentation.
The level of documentation released with datasets is based on the enthusiasm/drive of individuals involved in the release process.
Individual teams begin to create the essential documentation required to support some of the data they are releasing.
Some common templates or approaches are defined for  creating and managing documentation.
The organisation has identified a standard set of documentation and metadata that should be released with each dataset.
Only some, e.g. high-value datasets, are released with this standard set of documentation and metadata.
All datasets are released with supporting documentation and metadata using a standard template.
Creation and maintenance of supporting documentation is part of the data publishing process.
The organisation invests in additional documentation and supporting materials to help re-users.
The organisation routinely releases high quality metadata and documentation as appropriate for all of its datasets.
Externally published documentation is reviewed by key internal stakeholders before release.
Re-users are invited to provide feedback and contribute improvements to published resources. The organisation promotes the availability of third-party learning resources and tools.
No user support process.
Re-users need to seek out and engage with individuals in the organisation in order to ask for support.
No distinct monitoring or improvement of data use or issues.
Individual teams promote and provide ad hoc support for re-users of their data.
Some data releases may provide contact points for re-users to ask for support.
A few monitoring metrics have been defined, but are sporadically checked on a limited number of datasets. Issues are likewise handled inconsistently.
The organisation creates user forums as a means to enable discussion and collect feedback around datasets, and to communicate with its users.
Some metrics are routinely captured, and possibly automated.
The organisation has a central support team that helps re-users. This team is the primary means for re-users to seek help.
The organisation promotes the level of support available to re-users for all datasets, such as expected response times.
The organisation engages with re-users via multiple channels, e.g. social media, discussion forums.

A mutually supportive set of metrics has been decided on, following a focused iterative process. A number of these are automated. A feedback process is in place for data users, with issues frequently handled.
The organisation acts to measure the cost and efficiency of its support operations, and actively creates additional learning materials and community support groups as necessary.

The organisation ensures that it is delivering on its support arrangement for all datasets. For example, response times are within goals. The backlog of issues is relatively small, with no issue waiting for an extensive period of time. Difficult issues are used to improve the overall process rather than simply being handled on a case by case basis.
Most metrics are automated as much as possible, and are frequently reviewed and used for reporting and deciding on actions.
Data releases are unfunded and done as exceptional expenditure.
Procurement processes and contracts do not address data supply or re-use.
The organisation is unable to release any data that results from, or is derived from, existing contracts.
Individual projects may include open data publication costs as part of their budget, rather than addressing them separately.
The organisation begins seeking retrospective clarity around data rights regarding procurement. This is driven by the needs of specific projects that seek to open data.
Project funding and operational costs routinely include long term costs for open data publication. Responsibility for open data is explicitly part of specific roles.
The organisation begins tailoring individual contracts and procurement activities to address data licensing, as required by the needs of specific projects/products
The organisation actively monitors the financial costs and benefits of open data publication and re-use.
The organisation has clarity around costs and benefits of open data as part of ongoing data governance.
The organisation has standard clauses in contracts and ITTs to ensure clarity around data rights and re-use.
The organisation actively seeks efficiency savings around open data publication and re-use, such as by reducing data management and licensing overheads where possible.
All ITTs and tenders from the organisation include reference to open data where appropriate for the contract

activities.title: Understanding the value of open data

statements.text: No attempt is made to quantify the value of either published or re-used datasets.
The organisation carries out some reporting on the value of some datasets, e.g. to a specific community. The valuation is not quantified and is largely described in terms of general benefits.
The approach to valuation is ad hoc. For example, it may be done retrospectively to justify ongoing release of a dataset but is not always carried out prior to the initial release.
The organisation uses richly described, qualitative ways of demonstrating the value of publishing data across economic, social and environmental themes.
Where appropriate, the organisation begins defining more quantitative ways to measure the value and ROI.
Valuation decisions begin to inform the development of business cases in support of specific data releases.
The organisation adopts one or more standard approaches for describing, and quantifying where relevant, the value of its data assets.
Known re-uses and case studies are published alongside datasets.
This approach is applied to all key datasets, including those the organisation re-uses from third-parties.
The organisation routinely values all data assets. The valuation is used to drive all investment decisions relating to both data releases and use of external data.
The metrics and approaches to measuring value are regularly assessed to ensure they align with organisational goals. This information is openly published for transparency.
The organisation has no strategy or policy with regards to open data.
Initial data releases are seen as R&D exercises or are driven by external influence
Individual business units identify benefits of open data for their individual activities.
There is no coherent strategy across the organisation with regards to open data.
The organisation has an open data strategy. This includes elements addressed in other activities, including data valuation, governance, standards, etc.

There is clear responsibility and financial support for delivery of the open data strategy, at a senior management level. Ownership for key processes, such as data governance, is also well understood.
The organisation has aligned delivery of open data policy and strategy with organisational objectives, and this clearly supports the wider digital/data/AI strategy as well.
The organisation has set measurable targets for implementation of the strategy.
Performance assessment of key executives is tied to delivery of the objectives laid out in the strategy.
The organisation is using open data as a critical element of its overall organisational strategy.
Metrics and goals are reviewed and adjusted over time, to continue to stretch the organisation and to ensure that open data goals are consistent with other goals.
There is no methodical approach to managing data sources as assets.
Individual teams or projects maintain separate directories of data assets and data resources that they use. These are not orchestrated across teams.
An organisation wide data asset catalogue has been developed to identify key datasets being published and used.
All of the organisation's high-value datasets are in the catalogue.
Elements of the catalogue may be publicly and openly shared. For example, to identify datasets that are released, planned for release, or will not be released.
All datasets published or used by the organisation are entered into the asset catalogue, not just those deemed to be of high value.
New projects/products attempt to re-use datasets referenced in the catalogue, rather than creating new assets.
The organisation strives for cost and efficiency savings by identifying overlaps and commonalities between datasets, and either aligning or replacing them as necessary.
There is little to no understanding of the concept of data stewardship.
There are defined responsibilities in the organisation around data stewardship, including collecting, using and sharing data. There may also be a specific job role for these tasks.
The organisation has a clear, public identity as a steward of data, with committed actions and responsibilities as to how that manifests in reality.
These actions and responsibilities must  include publishing open data, and should include securely sharing sensitive data and building and maintaining data infrastructure.

There is a stated approach to data stewardship that includes an iterative, systemic process of ensuring that data is collected, used and shared for public benefit, while mitigating the ways that data can produce harm, and addressing how it can redress structural inequalities.
The organisation demonstrates clear leadership in responsible data stewardship, with a proven, public track record.
There are case studies with verified impact reports that demonstrate responsible data stewardship.
The organisation continues to drive and improve definitions of responsible data stewardship, and supports other organisations in their journey.
